utterances: And he made an interesting comment.
He said the U.S.
response hasn't been what we'd hoped for.
There's a kind of a history of Kurds in the region feeling betrayed by the U.S.
and others, so this comment might have some echoes of that.
Now over on the Turkish side, one Syrian national was reported killed in Reyhanli - that's a border town - when rockets came across from Syria.
Scores more people were wounded, and the military says it destroyed those launching sites.
Yeah.

So Guy, to put you on the spot, if the surge has had some success, do the military people that you speak with in pursuit of the stories you do feel that they have the strength to be able to maintain those numbers?
But, you know, Scott, a lot of those examples remind me of the ones I heard many times in my travels with the military in Iraq.
So are these latest examples any different?
I don't know, and I don't know whether we can really know for quite sometime.
Thank you very much.
NPR's Guy Raz at the Pentagon.
Thank you.
And now we thought we'd take this into the Barbershop.
That's where we gather a group of interesting folks to talk about what's in the news and what's on their minds.
Joining us for a shape up today are Jennifer Rubin.
She writes the Conservative ""Right Turn"" blog for The Washington Post.
Domenico Montanaro is political editor here at NPR.
They're both here with us in our studios.
Thanks for coming.
Hey there.
Nice to be here.
And with us from his home office in D.C.
in the D.C.
suburbs - OK, let's call it that - Ken Rudin.
He's a longtime political analyst and host of a radio show called ""Ken Rudin's Political Junkie."" Ken, thank you so much for joining us once again.
Michel, it's a secret location.
OK, it's a secret location.
We'll try to keep it secret.
One of us has to not be in the studio.
Exactly.
So we're going go back to this story that's really consumed us this hour - the many ups and downs in the saga of the Republican effort to repeal and replace Obamacare.

And as we all know by now, if we've been following this, House Speaker Paul Ryan announced that Republicans were pulling the latest bill rather than pushing a vote that did not have enough votes to pass into - here's President Trump speaking from the Oval Office a little later.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

But I'll tell you, what's going to come out of it is a better bill - I really believe a better bill - because there were things in this bill I didn't particularly like, and I think it's a better bill.
You know, both parties can get together and do real health care.
That's the best thing.
Obamacare was rammed down everyone's throat - 100 percent Democrat.
And I think having bipartisan would be a big, big improvement.
So no, I think that this is going to end up being a very good thing.
Jennifer, I'm going to go to you first on this because you've been writing a lot about this.
You've been pretty tough on pretty much everybody in the course of this.
But one of the things that caught my attention is where you said that there really was nothing inevitable about how this all played out, that deals could have been struck all along.
So just as briefly as you can, tell us where do you think things went off the rails, and do you agree with the president, that something good could come out of this?
I think it was wrong in substance, and it was wrong in process.
Somehow Paul Ryan got it in his mind that in 17 days he could introduce a bill, stick in front of his members, get it passed.
And by the end of that 17 days, I would venture a guess that maybe 20 people actually in the House knew what was in it.
It was changing all along.
And it became this sort of bastardized version, sort of Obamacare, not really Obamacare, repealing some of the regulations, not repealing some of the regulations.
So it was a substantive mess.

It was a, I think, a political disaster for Paul Ryan, who really for the first time had to try to govern, not only pass a bill but pass a bill that was going to be signed, which is a different exercise.
And yes, I think it was a debacle.
What could have been done differently?
Well, where was the president?
If he thought that bipartisanship was the way to go and that we could have a better bill, where's he been?
He is president.

Why didn't he tell Paul Ryan start the way President Obama did - it was a 13-month process, they had hearings, they had markups, the president went around the country, there was the big summit with the Republicans - and do the legwork to come up with a bill that you think can have some bipartisan buy-in.
That may have been very difficult, but no one said this was easy.
You know what?
I'm going to ask you later why do you think he didn't, but let me hear from Domenico on this.
Do you think - does this tell us anything about the prospects that the party faces?
This is unified government now.
I mean, the Republicans control every major branch of government, except for the judiciary, which is now, you know, 4-4 because of the vacant seat.
Does this tell us anything about the prospects for passing other parts of their agenda?
Well, it's certainly harmful.
I mean, this was a fundamental failure on all sides for Republicans.
I mean, this is something that they've been promising for seven years to repeal and to replace the - replace Obamacare.
I mean, this was what animated the 2010 elections, 2012, 2014.
And the fact that they didn't have anything ready to go is just a fundamental failure on all sides.

And for President Trump to show the kind of impatience he did to then deliver this ultimatum, which in ""The Art Of The Deal"" he talks about, you know, you've got to be willing to walk away from the deal and that should be the thing that is the lever that can get people to go - well, he put all his chips in and lost all of them, you know, and then walks away from it.
And somehow now he's going to reach out to Democrats, but they're not going to work on health care now.
They're going to move on to tax reform, and tax reform, by the way, is a lot harder than health care.
Ken, what do you think?
What do you think this means for the agenda of the Trump White House going forward and also congressional Republicans?

Well, if you make the argument that the House Freedom Caucus was emboldened by their opposition to Obamacare Lite (ph) as we heard Tom DeLay say, which is kind of funny, I mean - but if you think that the conservatives are more emboldened, then I don't see what you can do and what you can say that will bring along more moderates, let alone entice Democrats to come onboard.
Yes - it's interesting.
We talked about how the Democrats so-called rammed Obamacare down Congress's throat with no Republican votes.
But the point is Donald Trump did not reach out to any Democrat to make it a more bipartisan thing.
I agree with everything I've heard.
I think it's much easier to campaign than it is to govern, as Republicans are learning.
I think it's much easier to say no, because they've been saying no for seven years, than it is to say yes.
And I don't see how a new bill that brings along the conservatives would be any more palatable to the moderates who are nervous and the Democrats who just completely are against it.
But for all of that attention to the problem, the reconstruction has still not begun in earnest.
Some people are still waiting for insurance checks before they can start to work on their houses.
Besides the delays, there's another issue.
Before the storm, the Mississippi Gulf Coast was home to people of many different income levels.
And many are concerned that developers will only want to rebuild beach homes for the wealthy.
NPR's Kathy Lohr spent time in Mississippi talking to people who are having two very different experiences with rebuilding.
Tomorrow, she'll take us to trailer parks in Picayune and Waveland.
Today, Kathy Lohr introduces us to one man in Gulfport who is in an unusual situation - he has the money to rebuild his dream home close to the waterfront.
Jim Wetzel stands in the spacious foyer of his Georgian-style antebellum home, just off Highway 90.
The brick structure with a white porch and four white columns sits among dozens of lots that have been cleared along this stretch of coastline.
Wetzel says the strange thing is that Katrina left the second floor of his home intact, while it wiped out the entire first floor.
Everything in here was gone.
All we had was just a few two by fours holding up the whole structure, and I think what really held this structure up was the columns that I had.
The columns are made of solid brick, and Wetzel says they provided enormous strength.
The way the old masons used to do them back in the antebellum homes in Natchez, Mississippi and Port Gibson and Vicksburg, they'd brick them up and stucco them.
And I believe that's what held this house together, was strictly I've got the columns - columns in the front and the back - and it held this.
This is the only home standing.
There's only three homes on the entire beach, and mine's one of them.

Yet with the house so fragile after 29 feet of storm surge had washed inside it with the staircase torn away, and with the slab of marble and granite for a first floor, there were questions about whether to rebuild the home he patterned after century-old Southern mansions.
But Jim Wetzel grew up around here.
He's lived and worked as an attorney in Gulfport for 25 years.
This wall right here, this brick wall right here in front of my truck - that was all blown to the south.
That's all new that I put in there.
All that dirt was washed out.
See, when the water left out of here, and the surge came in, and then it went out so fast it took all the shrub and then it took that wall and blew it to the south.
There was no way it - you'd think it would be pushed in towards the house.
Wetzel, still so amazed by the destruction, shows some photos to one of the construction crews working on his home.
Although he was eager to get things back to normal, just across the highway from the Gulf waters his wife Garnette needed to be persuaded.
She was not really in favor of moving back.
The emotional toll that it takes on you, you know, do you want to go through this again?
And every time a hurricane season rolls around and you go through that same terror, that same fear - oh, my God, are we going to have to move out?
Are we going to have to move everything out of here?
Are we going to have something to come back to?
You know, do we want to do this again?
And I think, you know, it wears on people.
So you convinced her, basically.
I did, and I think that, you know, it took me many months -probably six to eight months to convince her.
(Soundbite of construction)
(unintelligible)
As carpenters measure, cut, and install custom mahogany cabinets in the kitchen, Wetzel smiles broadly to see just how much has been accomplished.
Part of what convinced his wife to come back was Jim's promise to return to the life the couple has known since 1987.
They raised their only son in this home.
Five days before Katrina hit, they celebrated their 30th anniversary here.
And Wetzel has plenty of dreams ahead.

It's nice to see, you know, things coming back into place, the time that you enjoy with friends and family in your home - I've had weddings here, I've had politicians here, you know, political parties.
I've had, you know, I've had wonderful times here with my wife and my family, and I cherish those and I want to have those back.
Wetzel knows he's one of the fortunate ones.
He had flood insurance and other insurance that's covered part of the cost.
He and his wife also had the fortitude and the means to come up with half a million dollars, the total price to rebuild here.
That courage led Gulfport Mayor Brent Warr to mention the couple by name in his state of the city address earlier this year, and to continue to see them as an inspiration to the entire region.
They didn't go out and promote themselves, they just got out and got to work, and that's what the entire state of Mississippi's done.
We've not complained and we've not bragged or begged.
We're not good at begging.
We're not good at asking for help, but we are good at working hard.
And that's what he did, and he's set a great example for all of us.
It's inspired me.
I have to drive by that house every day when I go to work, and I say, you know, if he can get out there and do it and keep his business going as well, so can I.
What you think about your back porch now, man?
It looks a lot better.
I'm telling you, it looks very good.
Two layers is really making it come out right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Wetzel is modest as he talks about his own contribution, but his eyes sparkle when he breathes in the salty air and thinks about the future.
